critique: This document pertains to the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933 and outlines the financial mechanisms for supporting the administration of industry codes. It allows Code Authorities to incur obligations, create budgets, and collect contributions from industry members, subject to the Administrator's approval. Members complying with the code and contributing to expenses are entitled to participate in the selection of the Code Authority and receive benefits. The document centralizes authority in the federal government through the Administrator's approval power and promotes government intervention in the economy by enabling industry codes and mandatory contributions. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, security vs. liberty, or social inclusion. The document expands executive power through the Administrator's role and favors federal control over state control.
